I commend the bill to the committee. Access Codes) Bill 1997 is designed to streamline the formal procedures for granting access to third parties to infrastructure facilities and networks of national significance by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. The bill proposes to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 to incorporate a general industry access code approval process as a basis for access undertakings in network industries. Under the current legislation, the ACCC has to conduct both a public consultation process for the industry code and separate public consultation for each access undertaking made by a service provider. It is considered that that is an unnecessary duplication of effort for the ACCC and for relevant stakeholders and could lead to difficulties for the ACCC in assessing whether separate access undertakings will achieve single coherent industry wide access arrangements. This legislation incorporates legislation which was considered by Labor in government and I think accepted by Labor in government but was not announced. The proposals improve the efficiency of the access regime approval process, we believe, without diminishing consumer or service provider protection. On that basis, it is supported by the opposition. It ought to be able to simplify and streamline the procedures for approving access arrangements to infrastructure services in network industries and build on the access regime established by the former government. Under these arrangements, third parties can seek access to services provided by essential infrastructure facilities of national significance. In network industries, such as electricity, the emerging pattern is for an industry code to be developed governing access arrangements which form the basis of undertakings to the ACCC by individual service providers. This morning, I want to call for this industry access code to go further and cover the petroleum industry. The reason I do so is that the petroleum and electricity industries in Australia have been remarkably similar in their structure and performance-that is, an homogenous product within a vertically integrated industry with natural oligopoly features at the point of production. Their only substantial difference has been that we had public ownership of electricity and private ownership of petroleum products. At a time when, under the banner of Hilmer and competition policy, state governments are vertically separating their electricity operations-generation, distribution and retail-why should petrol be any different? At a time when houses with solar energy units can join the national electricity grid, why should service stations not be able to buy their product from the most competitive source? Why should the Hilmer principles governing vertical industry separation and open access regimes not be applied to Australia's petroleum industry? My colleague the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham) has set out how this could happen. He said that a starting point would be to declare petrol refineries and terminals as an essential facility under the access regime. theText: I am sure the member for Werriwa( MrThursday, 20 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2655 This trade practices legislation is fundamentally about competition, which the member for Werriwa would be very keen about. The Productivity Commission's stocktake of microeconomic reform had this to say about competition: Getting more competition across the economy is now seen as a key to better performance. It provides a powerful stimulus for private and public firms to operate efficiently and respond to what consumers want. It encourages firms to search continuously for improvements in the way they operate, and is therefore vital to the process of productivity improvement through time. Competition is also central to ensuring productivity gains are shared with the wider community through lower prices. I entirely endorse those sentiments of the Productivity Commission. Regulation and monopoly and protection all encourage inefficiency and a misallocation of resources. Competition promotes efficiency and continuous improvement leading to consumer choice, better quality and lower prices. Most Australians are familiar with the benefits of competition in the sporting field. As Australia is a great sporting nation, it is appropriate that the Australian economy should be based on the principle that all sectors are exposed to the rigours of competing with each other and with the world's best. The sporting analogy helps us to understand the nature of competition-the way the competition encourages improvement, the way fair competition helps us to understand and respect the verdict of the umpire, and the way competition encourages cooperation between team members. The two concepts are not in conflict, as some people would claim. Nothing could be more removed from the Australian psyche than a desire to escape or avoid healthy competition. The most significant reform for the Australian economy over the past 15 years has beer, those reforms which injected greater competition. Two fundamental reforms stand out: the lowering of protection which exposed Australian firms to greater international competition-I note that the member for Werriwa has been supportive of the general move by the former Labor government to a lower protection regime-and the injection of competition into a number of the sectors of the domestic economy. Examples of this include the ending of the two-airline policy-all members would be aware of the improvement under the newer regime-the entrance of competition in the international, SID and mobile phone markets through Optus and Vodafone, the reduction in Australia Post's monopoly position, and state government moves to open up the electricity market to greater competition. I have had personal exposure to Australia Post's operation, and I say that they have become very competitive, both on an Australian market position and in comparison with other nations. I think that is because they have been open to genuine competition in some sectors of their markets whilst they do maintain a monopoly of the standard letter rate. This bill is part of a next step to a policy reform process. The Hilmer competition reforms are also known as the national competition policy and it dates back to the special Premiers conference in 1991. Until then the focus of micro-economic reform was on individual industries, for instance, the aviation industry, the automobile industry-which is now a focus
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Mcarthur
theText: That is right, they knew I was speaking, as the member for Fowler says.2656 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 March 1997 in the current debate-the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, postal services, which have been the subject of a number of government inquiries, Telecom and higher education. The national competition policy, flowing from the Hilmer report, is by contrast a national cross-industry initiative. Broadly, the policy requires governments to undertake the following initiatives: structural reform of their public monopolies; ensuring competitive neutrality-a level playing field is a term that a lot of people like to use-between the public and private sectors where they compete; conducting a review of all legislation which may limit competition; and ensuring access to essential infrastructure services for third parties. It is this final element which is dealt with by this bill. Under the Hilmer reforms, governments are required to look at the public businesses which have been traditionally regarded as natural monopolies. These industries, such as rail, electricity, postal and telephone services, have been traditionally regarded as services which only the government can provide. There can only be one rail network, one set of electricity wires and one set of telegraph poles. However, in the last few years we have come to question whether all these services really need to be monopolies and whether government really needs to be the provider. Under the competition policy, governments are asked to look at the possibility of separating aspects of these businesses which are natural monopolies and those which are potentially competitive. For example, railways have traditionally been regarded as being the domain of governments because of their natural monopoly characteristics. In other words, it is uneconomic to duplicate rail networks, and thus competition between rail tracks would be wasteful and costly. However, rolling stock, passenger and freight services are potentially competitive. Just as private cars, trucks and buses drive on public roads, there is no reason why private operators cannot use public rail tracks and compete vigorously with one another. By doing this, the natural monopolies-the roads, rail tracks, telephone wires or electricity poles-stay in government hands, but the private sector is allowed to offer services in the area where competition is possible. The greater the competition, the greater the incentive to raise quality, lower prices and give consumers choice. Competition between the SID telephone companies Telstra and Optus has had this result. Optus makes use of the Telstra network, just as different truck operators make use of the Hume Highway. This is the nature of what is called third-party access under the national competition policy. The bill before the House helps to streamline the mechanisms by which access can be negotiated and the terms and conditions of access to essential infrastructure like telephone networks, rail tracks and gas pipelines might be determined. It is pleasing to bring to the committee's attention that the electorate of Corangamite has been among the pioneers of private sector access to public rail facilities. In my electorate, West Coast Rail is among the first ever private passenger rail operator in Australia's recent history. The company negotiated access to the track between Melbourne and Warrnambool and runs a private service which was once run by the government owned V -Line. West Coast Rail now provides the only service from Warrnambool to Geelong, with three trains per day each way, and competes directly with V-Line on the Geelong to Melbourne route. We have a situation where this privati sed service has integrated into the V-Line network throughout Victoria. So on the one hand we see the public monopoly position operating, but with the new West Coast Rail service providing a service efficiently and effectively, and saving the government some $5 million. Thursday, 20 March 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 2657 The Victorian government was actually going to close that line. Now West Coast Rail has provided the service to the electorates of Corangamite and Warrnambool and provided a new concept of the way in which a private operator, owning its own rolling stock, might operate on the publicly owned track. We also see that TNT and the Specialised Container Transport Company are competing with National Rail on the standard gauge between Melbourne, Adeiaide and Perth, which incidentally runs through the electorate of Corangamite. Yesterday's Financial Review foreshadowed the possibility of the stevedoring firm Patrick's also becoming involved in rail freight operations on this route, which I commend as a desirable possibility. The Commonwealth's share of National Rail is set to be privati sed, along with the passenger service of Australian National and its freight arms in Tasmania and South Australia. But the standard gauge rail itself will stay in government hands and will be run by Track Australia, a specialist track management agency. This is a clear example of the separation of the functions which is possible, even under the traditional natural monopolies, under the Hilmer competition reforms. This bill deals with the rules about determining the terms and conditions of access to essential services, such as, the rail networks, electricity grids and gas pipelines where access is now being seen as an important prerequisite for real competition and, ultimately, lower prices. Under Part 3A of the Trade Practices Act, the relevant minister may declare certain essential infrastructure. This would require the infrastructure to be offered to those third-party users, potential competitors, under certain terms and conditions. Alternatively, the owners of this infrastructure, usually the government agencies, may offer access undertaking which would set out the terms and conditions under which it would offer infrastructure access to new players. The undertaking would set out all the terms and conditions that any new player would need to meet to be granted access. This undertaking would be submitted to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. The ACCC would advertise the offer, take submissions from interested parties, and undertake public consultations on the process. Of course, there would be industries where the access undertakings would be best done on a national scale. Instead of negotiating a series of different, independent access undertakings each with its own period of public consultations and submissions, it would be possible to have a national overall industry access code. This bill will facilitate that administrative change. The ACCC will be able to conduct public inquiries and take submissions on a national industry access code without going through the wasteful process of conducting a number of individual inquiries, consultations, and submissions from the public. The glaring example of where this approach is required is in the electricity market. Part of the national policy agreed to by the Commonwealth and the states requires the creation of a national market in electricity. The national market will soon commence involving New South Wales, the ACT and Victoria. Werriwa says, participation of Queensland remains in doubt at this stage, so I accept the interjection of the honourable member. If there is to be a national electricity market then access to electricity grids in each state should be determined by a national industry access code, not a series of individual access agreements as submitted to the ACCC. The latter would be an excessively cumbersome approach. Thus, this bill will be of vital importance in setting the arrangements for the national

theText: South Australia will follow suit at a later stage and, as the Member for2658 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 March 1997 electricity market. The national market will provide consumers in different states with unprecedented choice in where they source their power. Once again, Victoria has led the way in this reform by splitting up the old SEC into an electricity grid which remains in public hands. There are six electricity distributors, all now operating as private companies, such as Powercor, United Energy, Solaris, and Citipower. There are also a number of separate and largely privately owned electricity generators, such as Yallourn, Loy YangA and Loy Yang B, all of which can compete to supply electricity along the government-owned grid. Of course, if the private sector operators are to compete with the public sector on publicowned infrastructure, then we need a competitive neutrality. Competitive neutrality really means a level playing field between the public and private sectors. Often, government business enterprises enjoy some unnatural advantages over their private sector competitors. Many have traditionally been exempt from sales tax and other government charges. Others have had the benefit of government guarantees over their borrowings. State and federal governments are now being asked to neutralise these advantages so that public and private sectors can compete on an equal footing. The Victorian government has moved to impose debt guarantee charges on major government enterprises to remove any advantage they may have from the government guarantee over their debts. Another aspect of the competition policy is the requirement of conducting a legislative review. State and federal governments are supposed to look at any rules and regulations on the statute books which restrict competition. The governments must identify anti-competitive laws and determine whether those laws can be justified in the public interest. The public interest should include a broad range of factors, such as, the social welfare, ecologically sustainable development, regional development and occupational health and safety. Thus, even the Hilmer reforms recognise that unfettered competition may not always maximise the broad community welfare in all cases, although there is concern that governments are exempting certain industries from the Hilmer reforms even before they conduct the relevant reviews of the legislation. The National Competition Council, set up to advise the government on the progress of the competition policy, has already expressed doubts about decisions made by some governments. It has questioned the New South Wales government's decision to retain the existing arrangements for rice marketing. The honourable member for Werriwa and I would have some concerns about the monopoly position of that particular organisation; I have challenged it in the past. It has also questioned the ACT's shopping hour restrictions. These restrictions are the complete opposite of the Victorian government's decision to allow 24-hour trading, thus liberalising the market and removing several anomalies under prior restrictions. At the Commonwealth level, there are a number of industries which have also been exempted. The Wheat Board's single desk export monopoly is something that there is a considerable amount of debate on, on our side of politics, but in the broad thrust of discussions I think that, over the next 20 years, that monopoly position will certainly be questioned. The regional monopoly of local newsagents and the restrictions of home delivery of newspapers may be exempted from the scrutiny of the Trade Practices Act. Again, that is another quite interesting argument as to the monopoly of the news agents that has been maintained after a considerable amount of debate on both sides of the parliament. Thursday, 20 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2659 So the government needs to be vigilant about encouraging competition in all aspects. I notice that the honourable member for Werriwa is very keen on encouraging genuine competition between the oil companies and making sure that there is a fair and level playing field between the big majors and another couple of new entrants. I share some of those sentiments with him. I conclude by referring again to West Coast Rail. That concept of running a privatised rail in Victoria is leading the way and other state governments might follow the example and integrate, in a sensible and practical way, the operation of a private company using rail trackeither government owned rolling stock or their own rolling stock-and develop an integrated service within the total passenger service of the states or the Commonwealth. Then, over time, we can move away from this so-called natural monopoly of railways which has been the mindset of governments and, I think, of the Australian people since Federation. It was a step in the right direction. I am very confident that the new Howard government will follow on and make more accessible the whole idea of using the national standard gauge, like the national highway system, for access by private operators. In that way, the rail systems in Australia will become more competitive, more efficient and provide better transport for very heavy agricultural goods to the seaports. to respond on behalf of the government. theText: 2660 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 March 1997 The Tax Law Improvement Bill 1996 reflects the second tranche of the complete rewrite of the income tax legislation embarked upon by Labor through the tax law improvement project in 1994. On Monday, I am pleased to note, the Senate passed the first package of three bills that commence the rewrite. Labor supports this legislation as it is essential that the large and complex income tax legislation laws must be simplified, hopefully to reduce compliance costs for both taxpayers and the tax office, and to take the opportunity to improve certainty in cases where there is currently a great deal of tax law uncertainty. This whole process is necessary because the old legislation, the 1936 parent act, has been amended and expanded so often that it has lost an overall coherent structure. Because of the sheer enormity of the task, the rewrite has to occur in tranches. This ongoing rewrite process, piece by piece, provides its own challenges as it is not possible to repeal the entirety of the 1936 act and replace it in total. Labor does not criticise this process. Naturally enough, we understand it is the only realistic option. However, this process has produced some disquiet in some sections of the industry. There is a variety of opinions. Some believe that there should be absolutely no policy changes at all in the rewrite. For example, Price Waterhouse, as reported in the Financial Review in October last year, argues that the resources of the tax law improvement program should be redirected towards a tax reform task force-that is, change policy first and then rewrite the legislation. Clearly, Labor favours the current process which we instigated when in government. The Assistant Treasurer has the authority to make some small limited changes, especially to clarify the tax laws. However, this process should not be used to significantly alter policy more or less through the backdoor. Labor initially understood that the government agreed with this policy neutral project. However, this legislation, as introduced to the parliament, goes beyond a simple and neutral rewrite role. This particular tranche is being rewritten to address matters concerning assessable and exempt income, deductions, trading stock, depreciation and gifts. The more specialised areas include entertainment expenses and primary production. As with earlier bills, this bill was sent to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for consideration. The committee's report on the legislation, No. 348, was tabled in the House on 6 March. I am pleased to see in the chamber the chair of that committee, Mr Somlyay. I pay tribute to the work of his committee in the rewrite project because, in the parliamentary scrutiny, the rewrite brings forth a whole range of very complex and detailed matters in our taxation laws. To have a joint committee that so capably gets across all the detail and complexity, and provides due parliamentary scrutiny to the project, is absolutely critical. From time to time, there is too little public appreciation of the active role of committees such as the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in that parliamentary scrutiny. It is a very good thing that we have a committee that is well-led, well-resourced, and very active in making sure that the work of the tax officials in the rewrite project, and the involvement of the private sector, receives due parliamentary scrutiny. I pay tribute to the work and the report of the joint committee in that regard. I also endorse the way in which the committee appreciates that the best type of rewrite is a policy neutral rewrite. I note its concerns about the significant policy changes proposed within the bill. In particular, a concern arises about the proposed alteration of the depreciation provisions concerning hire purchase transactions, and the proposed alterations to the trading Thursday, 20 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 2661 stock provisions where assets change their character from normal business assets into trading stock, and vice versa. There is also a large number of minor technical amendments to ensure that the bill accurately reflects the existing law. Accordingly, the government has circulated numerous amendments; 83 in total. The opposition will not oppose any of these amendments. However, while being supportive of the project, we are concerned about the volume of amendments being presented to the parliament, and I am sure that that concern is supported by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and its chairperson. Perhaps part of the problem relates to the resourcing of the tax law improvement program. A vacancy has existed in one of the two private sector positions within the program since December 1995, 18 months ago-a vacancy for private sector resources to the program-and I note that the joint parliamentary committee has expressed concern about this delay. The joint committee has also suggested that additional resources be made available for the hiring, on a short-term basis, of private sector experts in particular areas to supplement the general program team. Labor supports this recommendation wholeheartedly. I note with concern, however, the cost to the public interest of the inadequate resourcing of a core government function-that of the major revenue authority, the Tax Office-and of private sector resources being harnessed for this particular program. I urge the government to take corrective action as soon as possible. It is an important point that too often in the public commentary, and too often under this government's budget management, it is assumed that every single budget cut and every single reduction in public resourcing is a good thing. But, clearly, the private sector can suffer much greater costs than the small public costs that are being saved. The cost to the private sector-to the accountancy and tax law industries and the small business sector, in particular--of delaying this tax improvement project is immense. For the government not to have filled a vacancy for some 18 months in the private sector resources that can be harnessed for the project really is an opportunity cost of folly. It is far better to resource this program fully, get the rewrite happening as fast as possible, have it approved by the parliament under the scrutiny of the joint committee, and allow certainty and simplicity to take hold in the tax law industry around Australia and in the understanding of those laws by private citizens and the private sector, particularly small businesses. The government needs to act on the recommendations of the joint committee to give this rewrite process full and adequate public sector resourcing. Other than making those comments, I will say that Labor will be supporting this bill and the circulated amendments, and we look forward to the further success of the rewrite program. reading the second reading speech by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister( Mr Miles), in which he said that the 1936 act was 'on the verge of collapsing under the weight of 60 years of constant and largely piecemeal amendment.' I have spoken to accountants about the income tax act, and they all say the same thing: it has become so heavy to lift that some of the staff are looking at putting in claims for back problems. It is about time it was reviewed and rewritten to make the act shorter, easier to understand, and with as few loopholes as possible. I want to pay tribute, as the former speaker did, to Mr Somlyay, who was here beside me today as Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I am advised that both New

speaker: Mr Zammit (Lowe) (11.03 A.m.)
theText: I want to make a few observations, especially after2662 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 March 1997 Zealand and Britain have a strong interest in looking at this project and undertaking to look at what they can do to amend their tax laws in line with the changes that we are proposing to make. That is a great tribute to Mr Somlyay and his committee, who have reviewed the bill. The rewritten areas that, in particular, I want to talk about are the areas that cover expenses, primary production deductions, the recoupment of deductible expenses and the sale of leased cars. I am advised by the accountants that I have spoken to about these issues that these are the issues that are most open to debate. As a result of that, of course, it costs the taxpayer money to have the matters resolved and costs the taxation department time, effort and money in trying to determine who is right and who is not right and in trying to interpret the intention of the act. I want to mention five points in particular. They are minor policy changes and I note that these changes have the support of the opposition. The five specific points that will make it easier, simpler and less burdensome for the taxpayer are: replacing the rules with which one facilitates taxpayer compliance; simplifying the rules which are unnecessarily complex; deleting unnecessary rules; removing anomalies; and clarifying ambiguities. Anyone who has anything to do with the income tax act will be very pleased that these changes will occur. The only other thing I would like to mention is that this will have no impact on revenue. It is basically a broadly neutral impact on revenue. It is about time that this has been tackled and, as I said, I want to pay tribute to Mr Somlyay and his committee for reviewing the changes and for making this possible. It will, in time, save us all a lot of time, money and effort and the taxpayers of Australia will be very pleased with these changes, not to mention the accountants, and those who go to them to seek advice and to understand the interpretations of the act, which have become very complex. I know in one particular case-my own case-I have sought a clarification from the Australian Taxation Office on matters that my accountant and I would like to dispute, and we have asked them for an interpretation of the act. We chose not to put in my tax return and to say that we have taken the deductions. If the ATO disagrees, they should advise us accordingly. We have decided that the best thing we can do is to ask for a clarification of the matters and then we will put in an amended return. It has now been close enough to six months and we still have not had a response from the Australian Taxation Office. I can understand the difficulty of the complexity in which they find themselves, trying to interpret something that should have been cleared up a long time ago. I fully support the bill. overhaul of our surfeit of tax legislation. What is different is that this message is now being driven, not only by industry and employer groups which have long championed tax reform, but also by social welfare groups, including the Australian Council of Social Service. The government finds itself in a position a little like Aladdin, inasmuch as the tax reform genie has been released from the bottle and simply will not go away. While the government has chosen to continue to grant two wishes, that is the rewriting and renumbering of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the clarification of ambiguities, it has, as its predecessor in government did, baulked at the third and unarguably most critical wish, and that is an overhaul of our byzantine tax policy. We are left, Mr Deputy Speaker, to tiptoe through the TLIPs, without even a suggestion of falsetto help from Tiny Tim. This bill is the second instalment of legislation to result from the tax law improvement project, which was established by the former Labor government on 1 July 1994. It deals with
